an6.36:4.1: “Mendicants, there are these six roots of quarrels.
an6.36:4.3: Firstly, a mendicant is angry and hostile.
an6.36:4.4: Such a mendicant lacks respect and reverence for the teacher, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and they don’t fulfill the training.
an6.36:4.5: They create a dispute in the Saṅgha, which is for the hurt and unhappiness of many people, for the harm, hurt, and suffering of gods and humans.
an6.36:4.6: If you see such a root of quarrels in yourselves or others,
an6.36:4.7: you should try to give up this bad thing.
an6.36:4.8: If you don’t see it, you should practice so that it doesn’t come up in the future.
an6.36:4.9: That’s how to give up this bad root of quarrels,
an6.36:4.10: so it doesn’t come up in the future.
an6.36:5.1: Furthermore, a mendicant denigrates and is insolent …
an6.36:5.4: with wicked desires and wrong view …
an6.36:5.5: They’re attached to their own views, holding them tight, and refusing to let go.
an6.36:5.6: Such a mendicant lacks respect and reverence for the teacher, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and they don’t fulfill the training.
an6.36:5.8: They create a dispute in the Saṅgha, which is for the hurt and unhappiness of many people, for the harm, hurt, and suffering of gods and humans.
an6.36:5.9: If you see such a root of quarrels in yourselves or others,
an6.36:5.10: you should try to give up this bad thing.
an6.36:5.11: If you don’t see it, you should practice so that it doesn’t come up in the future.
an6.36:5.13: That’s how to give up this bad root of quarrels,
an6.36:5.14: so it doesn’t come up in the future.
an6.36:5.15: These are the six roots of quarrels.”
